Week 1 ‚Üí Development Tools
Week 2 ‚Üí Deployment Tools

Language Setup & Config (bashrc, venv, nvm, etc.)

init, add, commit, push

Undo/redo commits


FastAPI Basics

Small Project ‚Üí Simple ChatBot (No Memory)
- Build a FastAPI endpoint /ask with Ollama (Gemma).
- Answers queries without history.

Docker/Podman

Dockerfile, Volumes, Networks

- FastAPI endpoint /chat with Gemini LLM.
- Maintains multi-turn memory in RAM.

Function Calling

Small Project ‚Üí PDF ChatBot
- Upload PDF ‚Üí Extract text ‚Üí Store in Vector DB.
- Build RAG pipeline with Streamlit UI + FastAPI backend.
- Multi-turn Q&A ‚Üí returns answer + page number.










Pydantic Models

Structured Prompts & Output Parsers

Chains & Runnables

Text Splitters

VectorStores in LangChain

RAG + Tool Calling


Small Project ‚Üí YouTube Playlist QA Assistant
- Scrape subtitles from each video of playlist.
- Store in a vector DB.
- Build chatbot ‚Üí answers video-specific queries.






‚ö†Ô∏è I Don‚Äôt have much knowledge on this topic.


Small Project ‚Üí *SQL Query Agent
- Convert natural language ‚Üí SQL query.
- Run on DB ‚Üí Return tabular results**.






Quarto + GitHub Pages

RevealJS Presentations

Markdown ‚Üí Website conversion

Excel Toolpack (Correlation, Regression, Data Analysis)

AWK Basics (text processing)


Small Project ‚Üí Portfolio Website
- Publish your portfolio with Quarto + GitHub Pages.













Voice-enabled AI Chat Assistant - üé§ Integrate STT + TTS + LLM.
- Speak ‚Üí Listen ‚Üí Respond in real-time.

title: Computer Boot Process: Essential Guide
text:
Overview
Boot Process Steps
Partition Styles vs File Systems
Boot Process Summary
Frequently Asked Questions
Resources




The computer boot process transforms your computer from powered-off state to a fully operational system. This guide covers the essential steps and concepts needed to understand how computers start.





When you press the power button:

CPU executes the first program BIOS/UEFI

BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) - Legacy firmware (used in old computers)
UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) - Modern firmware





POST (Power-On Self Test):

Tests CPU, RAM, and storage devices
Validates hardware components

Boot Device Selection:

Reads Boot Order from firmware settings
GPT drives: Looks for EFI System Partition
MBR drives: Checks Master Boot Record in first sector




Common Bootloaders:
Linux or Window bootloader, both can scan and start any OS windows or linux.
- Linux: GRUB2, LILO, systemd-boot - Windows: Windows Boot Manager
Bootloader Tasks:

Scans partitions for installed operating systems
Presents boot menu (if multiple OS found)
Loads selected OS kernel into memory




Linux OS Boot:

Kernel loads and initializes hardware
systemd starts (modern init system)
System services launch
User login interface appears

Windows OS Boot:

NT Kernel (ntoskrnl.exe) loads
Hardware Abstraction Layer initializes
Registry and system drivers load
Session Manager starts Windows subsystems
Windows Logon presents login interface







Partition styles define how a drive is divided into sections:








Feature
MBR
GPT




Max Partitions
4 primary OR 3 primary + 1 extended
128 primary


Max Storage
2 TB
18+ exabytes


Boot Support
BIOS only
BIOS + UEFI






File systems determine how data is stored within partitions:



File System
OS
Use Case




NTFS
Windows
System drives, large files


FAT32
Cross-platform
USB drives, compatibility


ext4
Linux
Linux system drives


APFS
macOS
macOS system drives










Phase
Component
Purpose




1
Firmware (BIOS/UEFI)
Hardware initialization


2
POST
Hardware verification


3
Bootloader
OS selection and loading


4
OS Kernel
System initialization



flowchart TD
    A[Power Button] --> B[Firmware Starts]
    B --> C[POST Check]
    C --> D[Find Boot Device]
    D --> E[Run Bootloader]
    E --> F{Select OS}
    F -->|Linux| G[Kernel + systemd]
    F -->|Windows| H[NT Kernel]
    G --> I[User Login]
    H --> I








Feature
BIOS
UEFI




Interface
Text-only
Graphical possible


Storage Support
2 TB max
No practical limit


Security
Basic
Secure Boot


Speed
Slower
Faster






Partition Style: Defines how the drive is divided (MBR vs GPT) File System: Defines how files are stored within each partition (NTFS, ext4, etc.)



Yes, by:

Installing each OS on separate partitions
Using a bootloader that detects all systems
Selecting which OS to boot at startup








Boot Process (English)
Boot Process (Hindi)
Windows Partitions (Hindi)

Component
Purpose




1
Firmware (BIOS/UEFI)
Hardware initialization


2
POST
Hardware verification


3
Bootloader
OS selection and loading


4
OS Kernel
System initialization



flowchart TD
    A[Power Button] --> B[Firmware Starts]
    B --> C[POST Check]
    C --> D[Find Boot Device]
    D --> E[Run Bootloader]
    E --> F{Select OS}
    F -->|Linux| G[Kernel + systemd]
    F -->|Windows| H[NT Kernel]
    G --> I[User Login]
    H --> I

title: Computer Boot Process: Essential Guide
text:
Feature
BIOS
UEFI




Interface
Text-only
Graphical possible


Storage Support
2 TB max
No practical limit


Security
Basic
Secure Boot


Speed
Slower
Faster






Partition Style: Defines how the drive is divided (MBR vs GPT) File System: Defines how files are stored within each partition (NTFS, ext4, etc.)



Yes, by:

Installing each OS on separate partitions
Using a bootloader that detects all systems
Selecting which OS to boot at startup

title: Computer Boot Process: Essential Guide
text:
Partition styles define how a drive is divided into sections:








Feature
MBR
GPT




Max Partitions
4 primary OR 3 primary + 1 extended
128 primary


Max Storage
2 TB
18+ exabytes


Boot Support
BIOS only
BIOS + UEFI






File systems determine how data is stored within partitions:



File System
OS
Use Case




NTFS
Windows
System drives, large files


FAT32
Cross-platform
USB drives, compatibility


ext4
Linux
Linux system drives


APFS
macOS
macOS system drives
